topics.body:
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55afda0c6368720a59000038#post_55afda0c6368720a59000038

What he said is that he knew it was going to happen about a week ago, and got out all of his sadness then. But if I woke up and the first thing my mom said to me was "What casket should we bury him in?", well, I'd kind of lose it, no matter how prepared I was. And he's sensitive, too, which makes this even weirder. 

If he's okay with it, I should be too since I really didn't know his dad, and most of my sadness was directed at my boyfriend and his family's loss. It's just bizarre.
topics.author: 5041b54f7f123b77af00a442

topics.body:
"@Too_Offensive":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55afda9863687209fd000101#post_55afda9863687209fd000101

Apparently, his dad was completely fine just a year ago. That's terrifying to think of.


"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55afdb1e6368720a59000194#post_55afdb1e6368720a59000194

I don't think I could even get out of bed for a few days. 


"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55afdb8f6368720a7b0001e0#post_55afdb8f6368720a7b0001e0

I've dealt with three grandparents. My dad's mother was probably the worse loss. She was literally the embodiment of sweet, elderly woman. The last time I saw her, it was obvious that she couldn't last much longer. It was like a textbook definition of terminal drop. She couldn't speak and only communicated through blinks. She tried _so hard_ to say hello to me for one last time that she ended up saying "Hi, Jessie" five times in a row. It was terrifying. 

"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55afdc7c6368720a5900034a#post_55afdc7c6368720a5900034a

It looks like something I can mercilessly rip apart.


"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55afdc7b6368720a7b0002ee#post_55afdc7b6368720a7b0002ee

Of course it does. :P
